The Giant Forest is an area with a high concentration of giant Sequoias; I think I read there are over 2,000 of them here. Apparently, the soil and climate are ideal for these trees. There are many trails running through this area and you can see many of the trees from the General’s Highway as well. The center of the area is the Giant Forest Museum, which is roughly 20 miles north of the park south entrance on the General’s Highway. Although Sequoia NP is huge and has many miles of hiking trails, the Giant Forest is arguably the best area to see these amazing trees. Anyone can intellectually understand the concept of a giant tree, but I did not appreciate the emotional impact that seeing these trees would create. As you drive or walk through the forest and encounter a sequoia towering over and dwarfing the other trees it has a definite impact. They are, quite simply, awe inspiring.

We thoroughly enjoyed our time in the Giant Forest. We only had one day so we used a tour company and being tired from travel across the country, we were truly happy to sit back and enjoy the views versus concentrating on driving the 100's of turns. Favorite stops were Sherman's Tree - spectacular but also VERY busy. You may want to try the morning to get a pictures without waiting. We enjoyed climbing Moro Rock. It take 15 - 20 minutes and almost everyone was huffing & puffing on the way up (approx. 6500 altitude at top) but on a clear day the views would be amazing. We had smoke from the Napa fires so the view was hazy but still worth the climb. It's a fun climb as it winds around, with passes that only one person at a time can navigate. The way down was easy & quick (not tough on my bad knees as some downward climbs). We stopped and took pictures at tunnel rock, the auto tree and other designed tourists areas when the park was first open. The true enjoyment is looking at the beauty of these trees - really awe-inspiring. If you are looking for wildlife, this park has black bear warnings but we did not see any and our guide said she has seen perhaps 10 all year. Take precaution but other parks on Montana & Wyoming would be more appropriate if wildlife viewing was a goal.

Highly recommend a hike on the Congress Trail after viewing the Sherman tree. The trail is about two miles, paved, and relatively flat. Lots of opportunities to get up-close to the giant sequoia trees.

As I learned about these trees since I was some 6, 7 years old and almost the other side of the planet, I always wanted to visit and check them close up.

Trust me, you are not let down if you love nature and unique things in general.

My partner bought the park tickets online and how inspired that was, as, accessing the park, there is a queue of cars on the left and on the right you can follow the cars of the people who work in the park, thus only showing your bar code for them to scan and access the park. However, buy your drinks and food to get you by as:
- you drive some 50km (the first 20 is probably only dangerous road as you go up towards the mountains where the Sequoia trees are)
- we realised we having been in the park some 4h, without doing any hiking, in order to visit most of the things mentioned here
- most of the 'attractions' mentioned here are grouped together, with the exception of General Sherman tree which is some 20km away from General Grant (where most of the people seem to go and take their pics)
- as we arrived at General Sherman's tree there wasn't almost anyone around
- do not keep food and water in the car for wild animals to see as there are bears etc, as the signs tell you
- there are no gas/petrol points in the park so fill in the tank before you access the park. I also noticed the petrol prices seem to be a bit higher in these little towns before reaching the park - it is their way of making their money, right?
- however there is a petrol station at Yosemite park, by contrast (we visited this the next day)
- be prepared for lots of very slow driving of up to 5miles/h, also even in September (on a lovely day though) there were some queues and you could not even turn around!!!!
- you cannot even overtake the very slow drivers if they cannot be bothered with the queues they produce
- I would expect at weekends, on lovely days, or summer time this place to be packed - which you might want to avoid
- as a driver it can become very tiring following all the twist, turns in the road etc. If I was to do this as a child probably I would have thrown up all the time
- we arrived via 198E, coming from Visalia, which was rather busy but we left via 180 after visiting Kings Canyon on the way to our hotel in Fresno

This is a must do stop in Sequoia National Park.

First, everyone else knows it is one of the key places to visit in the park - so be prepared for lots of cars and a possibly full parking lot. Don't get frustrated like Melissa R appears to have done - see earlier review. There are options like parking at the Giant Forest museum where there is much more parking and taking a shuttle or even parking there and walking the trails all the way up to the General Sherman Tree from there.

Regardless of where you park or how you get there - this is a place you want to go. And DON'T just stop at the General Sherman Tree. At least walk the Congress trail and get a little further into the forest where you can experience the awe of the natural world.

Many descriptions have been written to try and describe the feeling when you are among the giant sequoias but none of them truly do it justice. You just need to experience it for yourself. It is a bit like visiting a cathedral or other religious building, but one without walls and where God is truly the builder of the chapel.

The walk down from the parking area is a bit steep, but it is paved the whole way and there are steps. Once you get to the General Sherman tree area - KEEP GOING and explore further. From here the trail is mostly flat meandering up and down and looping around and around. There are literally 100s of trails so I would strongly recommend a map to help.

We came earlier in the season on a weekday and found parking right away - but if I had it to do again I would park at the Giant Forest museum and then walk along the trails up into the forest, stopping at the General Sherman tree before looping around to come back.

First of all, I'd like to let people know things that no one else wrote about. Once you pay your fee ($30 per car), there is a 17 mile almost the whole way there all winding road ( at 25mph) to where most activities are. So if you are prone to motion sickness do yourself a favor and prepare for this. There was about a 10 minute wait to even get to the entrance. Also, there is currently construction on the main road and in one area a one lane road where we waited 8 minutes for a light to change. Once we arrived to the area of general Sherman tree parking area there was no parking spots, so we were forced to create our own. Also, I checked ahead of time online to see if dogs are allowed, we got to the hiking trail only to find out pets are NOT allowed on ANY trails. Lovely, this would have been a great fact to know PRIOR to spending 4 hours getting there. The trail was well kept and the tree was nice to see. Follow Generals Hwy to Wolverton Rd and the summer parking lot for Giant Forest. If you have an ADA parking sticker/placard, you can continue further on Generals Hwy to a parking area with ADA accessibility to General Sherman tree. From the summer parking lot, we followed a 1/2 mile paved path with 200ft elevation change down to the tree. It may not sound bad, but it’s a pretty steep walk back out for anyone who isn’t in good shape, although there are several rest areas along the way. There’s a really cool viewing area just above General Sherman where the trail crosses a brick “footprint” matching the base of the tree. It provides a real perspective of just how big this tree is. Once at the base of the tree, we took the Congress Trail, a paved 2 mile loop that took us through many beautiful trees. It was one of my favorite “walks”. The forest was cool, quiet, and majestic…not to mention the wonderful aroma of pine. There are several other short trails nearby making this is a great place to piece together a longer loop with other trails, if you want a longer hike.

I like trees. I would not go so far as to say I am a tree-hugger, but Ive planted my share, can identify numerous different species, and have always admired the stoic majesty of a mature specimen. I had visited Sequoia National Park on my own years ago and it held such a place in my memory that I had to take my wife back to see it in September 2016. She likes animals but does not have the same nature connection that I do. That being said her eyes about popped out of her head as we were driving when we first started to see the "big" trees.
We walked a number of the trails around Giant Forest and other areas of the park. She was worried about bears and I tried to minimize her fears with proper bear protocol as well as the fact that I had never run into any in my 20 years of outdoorsing. Wouldn't you know she was walking a bit ahead of me on the trail and came walking back pale in the face saying "Bears in front of us!" I half thought she was kidding but wouldn't you know a mom and two cubs were walking the trail toward us. We backed out slowly without incident and left with a great side story.
The size of these trees puts a lot of things into perspective -- you realize just how little and young you are next to one of these thousands of year old giants.

I parked in the Sherman tree main parking area and walked the 1/2 mile trail down to the General Sherman Tree and the other areas nearby including a crosscut which shows the rings of a sequoia that is 2000 years old. There are a couple of trees you can get really close to, but most of the giant trees have a little railing around them to protect them from the millions of people that visit each year. I also hiked the Congress trail that splits off of the General Sherman trail. This trail is 2.1 miles and took over an hour to hike. Not sure why I am even writing a review, because it is clear that this place is amazing. But here is our visit in a nutshell...

Day 1 - 5 hour hike from the museum down around the meadows via Huckleberry Trail, until the High Sierra Trail, down and up Moro Rock, and back to the museum via the Soldiers Trail
Day 2 - 5 hour hike from the museum towards the General Sherman Tree via Alta Trail and then Circle Meadow, coming up to the Senate and House groups etc., and then returning via Rimrock Trail.
Day 3 - 2 1/2 hour hike from Crescent Meadow with a go and come back along the High Sierra Trail

Highlights:
- The trees obviously! You can travel the world visiting beautiful mountains and forests, but the Giant Sequoias are so unique and so impressive, it truly takes your breathe away at every corner.
- The wildlife: deer, squirrels, birds, and even saw a black bear cross my path on the last day!
-The peacefulness: with so many trails, the moment the you get away from the main tourists trails, you find yourself alone amongst the trees. We walked several times over an hour with crossing anybody.
-Trails: the trails are well maintained and easy to navigate. Also, there is not a very big elevation change throughout the park, so you can walk for hours and not be exhausted. It is basically like the ultimate nature walk!

Recommendation: if you want to do some hiking, buy the $3 map at the museum, it is totally worth it.

We also wanted to visit Crystal Caves, but the tour was cancelled at the last minute because some rocks had fallen across the path and was deemed too dangerous. (This is why our Day 3 hike was only 2 1/2 hours!!:) Buy your tickets early, because it will sell out!!

Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Park (California)
Quick Facts
Best hikes: General Sherman & Congress Trail, Panther Gap via Long Meadow, Moro Rock
When to visit: This park gets quite a lot of snow and closes a lot of its trails in the winter months, summer is the best time to visit.
Do I need a hiking permit? No.
Sequoia is a very picturesque National Park with an abundance of wildlife including black bears, marmots, deer, chipmunks and squirrels. A lot of the popular sites can be viewed by car and require minimal walking, however if you are interested in something more challenging you can take on Panther Gap. This hike weaves its way up the mountain and provides spectacular views of the valley, provided the clouds aren’t low lying like they were the day we went.
